title: Enable nightly builds for Python wheels
body:
Enables nightly builds for Python wheels via GitHub actions. Builds start at 12am Pacific (7am UTC) and take around 30 minutes to finish. Also updated the script for building wheels.

This should be merged after #143.

title: Release v0.3.1
body: Bumps versions to 0.3.1.

title: Updated crate dependencies.
body: Updated dependencies so that we can benefit from the newer Tokio features (e.g., https://tokio.rs/blog/2020-04-preemption).

title: Simplify and document OperatorConfig builder pattern
body: Also updates documentation for `JoinOperator` and `MapOperator` to fix builder pattern, rename streams, and hide lines unnecessary to the example in the documentation.

title: Update comments
body: Update comments from yesterday's design meeting.

title: [BUG] Default to None if name of callback not available.
Documentation and logging for Rust streams.
body:
- Added documentation for Rust streams.
- Removed the instances of logger being passed around in OperatorExecutor. Everything uses `crate::TERMINAL_LOGGER`.
- Added a `new_with_name` to all streams to match existing function on IngestStream.
- Cleaned up API and fixed some inconsistencies.

title: Logging and Documentation for Python API of ERDOS.
body:
- Introduces a `logger` in the top-level ERDOS module that users can use to enable more verbose logging for Python.
- Improves documentation for front-facing Python classes and functions.
- Adds type hints wherever possible (unsure about the TODOs since the API does not seem to be well-formed there)
- Introduces a `name` property in all the Streams (default: `None`) that future refactorings of the Rust codebase will automatically populate for the Python streams (for now).

title: Refactor operator event ordering and lattice
body:
- Changes operator event ordering s.t. `x < y` implies `x` *precedes* `y`.
- Reverse edges on lattice dependency graph to match [convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_graph).
- Add warning if more than 25 events queued in lattice.
- Add `to_dot` method to lattice for easier visualization/debugging.
- Code refactoring and comments on lattice.
- Tests use `assert` instead of `assert_eq(*, true)`.

title: Added join method on a node handle.
body: The join can be used to block until all process from a node complete.

title: Sigkill processes if they do not terminate.
Configure number of streams in bundles with environment variables
body:
Introduces `ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_READ_STREAMS` and `ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_WRITE_STREAMS` which parametrize the maximum number of read and write streams in bundle. This allows constructing bundles over more than the default number of read/write streams without modifying `build.rs`.

Other changes:
- Pylot compatibility:
  - `ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_READ_STREAMS` defaults to 20.
  - `ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_WRITE_STREAMS` defaults to 10.
- Logging in `build.rs`.
- Extend `make_callback_builder.py` to support up to 99 read/write streams.
- Configure `build.rs` to only re-run on build if `build.rs`, `make_callback_builder.py`, `make_add_watermark_callback_vec.py`, `ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_READ_STREAMS`, or `ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_WRITE_STREAMS` are changed.
- Add README section on build parameters.

It turns out that compiling generated code dominates build times, which is quadratic in the maximum number of read/write streams supported by bundles `O(ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_READ_STREAMS * ERDOS_BUNDLE_MAX_WRITE_STREAMS)`.
![erdos-build-time](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14067561/87897405-16d3a000-ca00-11ea-9a40-73ae66cc2acb.png)

title: Implement fine-grained ordering for OperatorEvents
body:
This PR takes implements a more fine-grained ordering for OperatorEvents, which is enforced by the ExecutionLattice.

Before, ERDOS merged callbacks from watermark callbacks and bundles into a single OperatorEvent. This resulted in bugs where flow_watermarks may run before other watermark callbacks. By un-bundling such OperatorEvent, defining a more fine-grained ordering which takes into account state dependencies, and taking advantage of priorities (#130), such bugs should be fixed.

Other changes:
- Added a `add_watermark_callback_vec` function so Python watermarks flow the same way as Rust watermarks.
- Added `make_add_watermark_callback_vec.py` script which code-gens part of the `add_watermark_vec` function. It generates logic similar to the manually implemented and newly deleted `add_watermark_callback` in `python/py_streams/mod.rs`.

Also, the PR is missing tests. I'm happy to add a few if they're necessary.

title: Add Priorities for OperatorEvents
body:
Can add priorities to callbacks which are exposed via a bundle's `add_watermark_callback_with_priority` method.

Some details:
- Smaller numbers imply higher priority.
- Priority currently only affects the ordering and concurrency of watermark callbacks.
- For two otherwise equal watermark callbacks, the lattice creates a dependency from the lower priority event to the higher priority event. Thus, these events cannot run concurrently, with the high-priority event running first. An effect is that only watermark callbacks with the same priority can run concurrently.

Unfortunately, this doesn't solve the flow watermarks bug by itself due to the way operator events are created, which I'll take a look at next.

title: [Python] Update documentation
body:
Updates Python documentation and adds building Python documentation to CI.

You can view the updated documentation [here](https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~pschafhalter/pub/erdos/pydoc/) (I might take this offline after the PR gets merged).

title: Replace fire with argparse
body:
Replaces fire with argparse in the Python script that generates the callback builders.

This change removes a step from the install process.

title: [Rust] Fix new nightly errors
body:
- The Rust specialization feature rust-lang/rust#31844 is unsound and throws a warning on the latest nightly. This PR moves to min_specialization which fixes the warning.
   - [Forks abomonation](https://github.com/erdos-project/abomonation) in order to allow specialization on structs that implement `Abomonation`.
- Replaces use of `Vec::remove_item` to end reliance on the deprecated `vec_remove_item` feature.

title: [Rust] Improve documentation
body:
- Improves existing documentation across the crate.
- Hides documentation for internal data structures that are public by necessity due to macros (e.g. `InternalReadStream`).
- Moves macros to a separate `connect.rs` submodule to clean up `lib.rs`.
- Adds building documentation to CI. This is in a separate workflow file so that we have the option to host up-to-date documentation for the current master in the future.

You can view the updated documentation [here](https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~pschafhalter/pub/erdos/doc/erdos/) (I might take this offline after the PR gets merged).

title: Use GitHub Actions for CI
body:
Switches to GitHub actions for CI. The checks don't run on this PR, but you can see them in action at pschafhalter/erdos#1 and clicking on the "Checks" tab. Hopefully, GitHub Actions will work for this repo as well after this PR is merged.

### Changes
- Deprecate Travis and move to GitHub Actions
- Target multiple Python versions (3.6 and above)
- Check formatting of Rust and Python files
- Fix formatting

### Why GitHub Actions?
- Easier to target multiple Python versions
- Able to get `rustfmt` working even when it [fails on the latest Rust nightly](https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-toolstate/)
- More concurrent jobs (20 with GitHub Free/40 with GitHub Pro)
- Flexible for future automation, such as adding workflows for packaging releases

title: Fix warnings
body:
Fixes warnings when building ERDOS, tests, or the documentation.

Also fixes a minor bug introduced in the python bridge.

Makes variable naming in the tests more consistent.

title: Reorganize modules to restrict visibility
Extended macro builder to support operators with more input streams.
Remove Eurosys throughput experiment and plotting scripts
Implement zero-copy communication
body:
- Adds zero-copy communication for operators colocated on the same node.
- Zero-copy mechanisms speed up cross-node communication by reducing copies on the communication path.
- Further speed up cross-node communication by serializing directly into the network buffer.
- Operators receive references to timestamps and messages rather than taking ownership to further reduce copies.

title: Use a BinaryHeap to order events.
body:
- This change uses a BinaryHeap instead of a Vec to order events that are ready to run. (hopefully prevent starvation)
- Adds a new test to ensure that the behavior is as expected.

title: Revert "[Python] Remove duplicate flow watermarks implementation"
body: Reverts erdos-project/erdos#116

title: [Python] Remove duplicate flow watermarks implementation
body: Removes obsolete python implementation for flowing watermarks.

title: [Python] Fix bug in erdos.reset()
body: Fixes a bug where ERDOS would launch too many python processes after resetting the dataflow.

title: Fix macro imports for external crates
body:
Re-exports crates used in ERDOS macros so that crates using ERDOS don't need to explicitly import them.

Before, crates using ERDOS would need to add dependencies for slog and tokio in `Cargo.toml`.
This is no longer necessary now.

title: Enable processing callbacks in parallel
body:
Adds the `num_event_runners` setting to `OperatorConfig` which sets the maximum number of callbacks an operator can process in parallel.

This PR is a step towards implementing multi-threaded operators.

title: [Python] Replace operator with Map in example
[Rust] Add latency benchmarks
body:
Adds latency benchmarks using criterion.

Also adds `erdos::reset` which resets the internal dataflow graph, allowing a program to stop a dataflow, reset the graph, and create new dataflow graph.

Contains some minor bugfixes as well.

In addition, ran the benchmarks on erdos4:
[report.zip](https://github.com/erdos-project/erdos/files/4384881/report.zip)

title: Call Operator::run from OperatorExecutor to remove busy-looping
body:
OperatorExecutors now call `Operator::run` from an async context. This allows waiting on the `RunOperator` signal using a blocking call instead of busy-looping.

Also fixes some bugs in the tests.

Fixes #102.

title: [Operators] Replace CHashMap with locked HashMap
body:
Also did some cleanup to reduce build warnings.

Fixes #100

title: [Python] Added window map example, modified import statements in submodule
Implement ExecutionLattice to partially order incoming events.
body:
- Adds a dependency to `petgraph` which provides the underlying directed acyclic graph implementation.
- Implements the `PartialOrd` trait for the OperatorEvent to partially order events based on their timestamps and watermark status.
- Implements the `ExecutionLattice` class that partially orders the incoming events and provides an API to retrieve the events that are safe to run.

title: Make pyo3 an optional dependency
body:
Minor fix which improves build time by making pyo3 an optional dependency. This improves build time when building the core system.

This PR doesn't change the build process; pyo3 is automatically included when building for python.

title: Add time-versioned state to enforce determinism
body:
Adds time-versioned state which ensures that an operator behaves deterministically while allowing as much parallelism as possible.

Time-versioned state enforces 3 different access patterns:
1. When created in Operator::new(). This allows setting the number of past states accessible via the history size and an initial state associated with `Timestamp::bottom()`.
2. From a regular, non-watermark callback. This allows appending messages which are later exposed to watermark callbacks. Appended messages may be compressed versions of ERDOS messages.
3. From a watermark callback. This allows reading appended messages and reading state up until current timestamp. In addition, it allows mutating the state associated with the current timestamp.

For each access pattern, access rules are enforced via the `AccessContext`. ERDOS manages transitions between `AccessContext`s.

Time-versioned state currently has the following weaknesses:
1. Manual GC. Currently, users must manually do `time_versioned_state.close_time(t)` to GC message and state history. This potentially introduces non-determinism in states shared across multiple streams. Fix this by pushing GC to ERDOS; when the last watermark callback for the state at time `t` runs, we can close time for `t`. Unfortunately, this requires logic not currently implemented in ERDOS.
   1. Make an issue for this after merging.
2. Ordering of messages in vector. Watermark callbacks that behave differently depending on the ordering of appended messages will behave non-deterministically. This can be solved by using an unordered collection or sorting the vector before exposing to the user, but these may impact performance or adds more restrictions on what can be appended (e.g. a HashMap with a count requires that the Hash trait is implemented).

title: [Python] Enable shutting down dataflows
body:
`run_async` now returns a `NodeHandle` which implements the `shutdown` method for the dataflow.

For example:
```python
node_handle = erdos.run_async()

node_handle.shutdown()
```

Other changes:
- updated the close stream example to shut down.
- fixed a bug that caused errors when `config.name` is `None`

title: [Python] Added window and map operators to operators submodule
Ensure @erdos.profile_method works on all types of operator methods.
Log trace events in json format.
[Bug] Updated add_watermark_callback bindings to pass is_top.
[Doc] __init__.py connect method and typos in html
Fixing connect macros.
body:
This commit fixes connect_2_write and connect_3_write macros.
Introduces tests to ensure connect_2_write! and connect_3_write! are tested.
Refactors connect macros to reduce the number of branches.

title: Add operator destructors and allow closing streams
body:
This PR adds operator destructors by implementing Operator::destroy which are invoked when all of an operator's read streams are closed.

To close a read stream, send a top watermark e.g. with `Message::new_top_watermark()`.

Also makes several improvements to the Python/Rust interface, and adds tests and examples.

title: Extended operator API with method to get runtime statistics.
body: - Introduces a get_runtime method in operators. This method can be used by callbacks change adjust behavior depending on time to decision and estimated runtimes.

title: MapOperator and JoinOperator Implementation.
body: - This PR provides the implementation of MapOperator and JoinOperator along with the relevant tests.

title: [Python] Add OperatorConfig
body:
Adds an `OperatorConfig` class which must be passed into `erdos.connect`, matching the Rust API.

Also adds the `config` property to the `Operator` base class.

title: Added decorator for profiling operator methods.
[Python] Add name and ID properties to erdos.Operator
body:
Adds name and ID properties to python operators. These can be accessed as `self.name` and `self.id`.

In addition, moves setup for `_trace_events` to the `__new__` function. This avoids forcing users to call the `erdos.Operator.__init__()`. We might change this in the future.

Note that the `uuid` package is available in python 3.5+.

title: Added with statement for profiling operators.
Operators must implement Operator trait
body:
- Renames `OperatorT` trait to `Operator`.
- Removes `get_name` and `get_id` methods from `Operator` trait.
- Add compile-time check that operators implement `Operator`.

title: Remove ReadStreamT trait
body: Removes the `ReadStreamT` trait since it is unused/unnecessary in its current state.

title: Fix hanging tests
body:
Fixes #61. This PR assigns unique ports to each node used in a test.

Previously, `cargo test` would run tests in parallel in separate threads. Nodes requested the same ports which occasionally resulted in deadlock if one test acquired the control port and another acquired the data port.

Thanks to shepmaster whose [solution in this thread](https://users.rust-lang.org/t/unique-id-per-test/33882/4) was adapted into the fix.

title: Implement shutdown for nodes
body: `Node::run_async` returns a `NodeHandle` which exposes `join` and `shutdown` methods. `join` blocks until the node finishes. `shutdown` sends a shutdown message to the node, and then blocks until shutdown is complete.

title: Decrease indents in macros
body: Cosmetic change which reduces the number of indents in macros by 1.

title: Implement exporting dataflow graph to DOT file
body:
Introduces an API to export the dataflow graph to a [DOT file](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOT_(graph_description_language)).

In Rust CLI, do `-g=dataflow_graph.dot` or `--graph-filename=dataflow_graph.dot`.

In Python, do `erdos.run(driver=driver, graph_filename="dataflow_graph.dot")`.

In Rust, labels operators with provided names or falls back to operator ID. In python, labels operators with class names. Streams are labeled with Stream IDs.

Example for `python/examples/simple_pipeline.py`:
![simple_pipeline](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14067561/75126545-4bb91200-566f-11ea-96f6-1bf52bcb66db.png)

title: Remove python driver function
body:
API-breaking PR which removes the need to pass a driver function to `erdos.run()` and `erdos.run_async()`.

This PR simplifies the python API and removes a bug in which python nodes had superfluous copies of the dataflow graph.

title: Move streams and operator executor to Tokio
body:
- Avoids busy looping for invoking callbacks by moving streams and operator executor to tokio.
- Replaces std channels with tokio channels to prevent blocking of OS threads (which may cause starvation/block the entire runtime).
- Calls to `ReadStream::read` now busy loop, but don't interfere with the runtime. To solve this issue, we may want to move operators to tokio in the future, make `run` async, and implement an async `ReadStream::read`.
- Fixes a bug in the single node case where `Node::run_async` may finish running while operators should still be running.

Performance of `python/examples/watermarks.py` before fixes (note 3 CPUs at 100%):
![cpu_no_tokio](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14067561/74675960-b2b76200-5169-11ea-9a23-3d10a06405f9.png)

Performance of `python/examples/watermarks.py` before fixes (note 1 CPU at 100% due to `PullWatermarkListener`):
![cpu_tokio](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14067561/74675984-c4990500-5169-11ea-88c0-fea50a12d9cd.png)

title: Verify that corresponding types in `new()` and `connect()` match
body: I couldn't find a better way to do this type checking at compile time -- the closest I got was [`std::compile_error`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/macro.compile_error.html), but I couldn't find a way to interface this with the type checking.
